Report: Creative industry provides 60,000 jobs

Creative industry strong with potential to grow, says Kentucky Arts Council report

Report: Creative industry provides 60,000 jobs

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 7:56 a.m. EST December 3, 2014

Emily King and Lucas Melsha perform in Loves Labours Lost at Actors Theatre of Louisville in September.(Photo: Actors Theatre of Louisville)

Story Highlights

  • Number of Kentucky's creative industry jobs ranks higher than auto manufacturing, says report.
  • The Kentucky Arts Council presents the report Wednesday at its Kentucky Creative Industry Summit.
  • Policies to support the creative industry could include no sales tax on art sold in certified cultural districts
  • .
14 CONNECT 8 TWEET 1 LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Among workers employed in Kentucky, 2.5 percent are in jobs that fall under the creative industry, according to the Kentucky Creative Industry Report unveiled Wednesday by the Kentucky Arts Council.

The report also asserts that businesses in Kentucky's creative industry provide more than 60,000 jobs and accounted for nearly $2 billion in total earnings in 2013.

"I'm hoping the creative industry can get leverage from this," said Lori Meadows, executive director of the Kentucky Arts Council. "I feel like the report has crucial data to encourage investment."

She said that investment could come from private sources as well as all levels of government.

The report covers creative work encompassing visual art and crafts, graphic design, film and media, folk arts, writing, advertising, music, theater, web design, product design, dance, architecture and interior design. It was conducted by Mt. Auburn Associates, a consulting firm that did its first creative industry report for Massachusetts more than 10 years ago and has since worked on similar reports for public and nonprofit institutions throughout the country.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Findings from Kentucky Creative Industry Report

"With the arts, we still think of it too much as something people donate to and an afterthought of economic development," said Stuart Rosenfeld, a consultant who worked on Kentucky's report. "It's not considered as something that generates wealth and employment."

The report's authors consulted surveys, conducted interviews and focus groups and referred to the Arts and Cultural Production Satellite Account, a national document produced by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis and the National Endowment for the Arts last year. It was the first time the federal government has made a detailed account of how the art and culture industries contribute to the economy.

Released last year, that report estimated that in 2011 arts and culture production constituted 3.2 percent, or $504 billion, of gross domestic product, which was greater than the travel and tourism industry's 2.8 percent.

"There's a momentum behind measuring the creative economy," said Bonnie Nichols, an NEA analyst who worked on the federal report. "You have to understand that the United States has a comparative advantage with an ideas-based economy. Those looking for GDP growth are looking more to the creative side in an ideas-based economy."

Camparion to other sectors graph.(Photo: Ky. Arts Council report)

This federal report also detailed the jobs in arts and culture industries. Rosenfeld said different states and other localities don't use all of them but select the jobs most strongly linked to that place's culture. For instance, some, like Louisiana, have included the culinary sector. While Kentucky's report discusses the culinary sector, Meadows said it did not count jobs from that sector for its report.

"We tried to be conservative, but if you look at that, Kentucky's creative industry is stronger than many other sectors, including the auto and aircraft manufacturing industry," Meadows said.

Before commissioning the report, the council also looked at what other states had done, particularly Louisiana. That state's first report on its creative industry, in 2005, found that it comprised 7.6 percent of the work force.

Louisiana's report was released just four days before Hurricane Katrina hit, recalled Pam Breaux, the assistant secretary of the state's Office of Cultural Development, but it didn't get lost in the response to the destruction. Instead, it helped guide the state in helping communities bolster their local economies, Breaux said, as Louisiana began creating programs and policies from that report's data.

Those policies have included sales tax incentives and tax credits for rehabilitating historic properties. For instance, shoppers who purchase art in cultural districts don't pay sales tax. That, she said, has led to a significant increase in sales of art. She added that as more historical properties are being rehabilitated, blight is down and artistic activity is up.

Since 2005, Louisiana has generated updated reports on its creative industry twice in 2007 and 2010.

"What's been important is to build a program that can track data that we can report back to the legislature," Breaux said. "We track the data district by district every single year, and it's hard work, but, boy, it pays huge rewards."

It will be years before Kentucky is in Louisiana's position, but Meadows said Kentucky's report gives the state a starting point.

"We now have much better data to show that, yes, Kentucky has a strong creative industry and there is a value to further investing in that sector," she said.

The arts council's first step is to change a vacant position in its office into a new post for a creative industry director or manager. That will give the council someone who will focus on the report and its recommendations.

"The next stage is getting this into a policy agenda," Rosenfeld said. "The challenge in Kentucky and other places is getting economic development people to understand the economic potential of creative industries and begin to invest in them. We have to formalize the linkages between the arts and departments of education and work force and economic development."

The report gives the council a long to-do list in the form of recommendations. These include staging an annual creative industry conference starting in October; using creative resources to assist schools in implementing the National Core Arts Standards in the K-12 school system; expanding business services and workshops for entrepreneurs in the creative industry; establishing a Kentucky business advisory group on art and design; and connecting artists and artisans to architects and builders.

With all the focus on creative industry, some arts leaders have voiced concern it could hurt traditional arts organizations, many of them struggling in an economy with fewer government and sponsorship dollars coming to them. One of them is Richard Evans, an arts industry expert and president of the New York-based consulting firm EmcArts.

"The term creative industries can also be defined to go so far beyond arts into creatives at ad agencies, into hair salons, etc. that it's meaningless or is of little applicability to the traditional not-for-profit sector," Evans said. "It could even pull investment attention toward for-profit commercial interests at the expense of social investment."

Andrew Kipe, executive director of the Louisville Orchestra, said he doesn't envision that scenario. He believes traditional arts groups can benefit from the results of the data.

"The impact of creative industries as a whole on a community or state as a whole often gets lost in the mix," Kipe said Tuesday. "This initiative gives us another opportunity to tell how arts organizations are important to communities."

With the report's release Wednesday, the Kentucky Arts Council is taking an immediate step to start talking publicly about the report and its breadth. It will hold what it calls the Kentucky Creative Industry Summit at the Kentucky Center in Louisville.

The summit will include an overview of the report presented by Rosenfeld and fellow consultant Robert Donnan, as well as remarks by Kentucky Lt. Gov. Crit Luallen and Tourism Arts and Heritage Cabinet Secretary Bob Stewart. It also will include leaders of projects from other parts of the country considered to be part of the creative industry in talks about partnerships across industries and funding.

Reporter Elizabeth Kramer can be reached at (502) 582-4682. Follow her on Twitter at @arts_bureau.

CREATIVE INDUSTRY SUMMIT

When: 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Wednesday

Where: Kentucky Center for the Performing Arts, Todd Hall, 501 W. Main St.

Registration: Required. Visit artscouncil.ky.gov/Opportunities/CreativeIndustrySummitAgenda.htm
